data.description: The organization has devised and implemented a responsible data strategy that prioritizes data privacy and promotes more ethical uses of data, including disposal and data sustainability practices.

criteria.title: Privacy Policy
criteria.description: The organization has a public-facing privacy policy in place and supports existing privacy laws such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), and so on. This policy must be both accessible for all visitors, including those with accessibility and reading comprehension needs, and abide by plain English best practices to avoid jargon, technical language, and legalese.

criteria.title: Data Ownership
criteria.description: The organization can show measurable progress over time on how it respects data privacy and ownership, including a visitor's "right-to-be-forgotten" and provides the ability to export data.

criteria.title: Data Protection
criteria.description: The organization supports new and emerging legislation related to data privacy, data sustainability, and responsible data practices.

data.title: 5.21 Implement Appropriate Data Management Procedures
data.description: Expired or unused data has a cost, it takes up space, and it requires maintenance. As such, the ability for customers to manage their own data and for service providers to manage older website material which no longer applies but might still have use will be a carbon benefit.

criteria.title: Outdated Content
criteria.description: Outdated or otherwise expired product content and data are archived and deleted via automated expiration dates and scheduled product audits. Create an archiving schedule with a lighter version of the old searchable content available.

criteria.title: Data Controllers
criteria.description: Enable users to control, manage, and delete their data, subscriptions, and accounts.

data.title: 5.22 Promote and Implement Responsible Emerging Technology Practices
data.description: The organization has devised and implemented responsible policies related to artificial intelligence, Internet of Things (IoT), blockchain, and related emerging technologies.

criteria.title: Emerging Technologies
criteria.description: The organization has public-facing policies in place for emerging technologies, and all such technologies are ethically sourced, screened, validated, and implemented in a non-discriminatory, responsible manner.

criteria.title: Disruptive Technology
criteria.description: The organization can show how it up-skills workers as new technologies and practices potentially disrupt its business model.

criteria.title: Technology Legislation
criteria.description: The organization supports responsible legislation related to automation and emerging technologies.

data.title: 5.23 Include Responsible Financial Policies
data.description: The organization implements responsible finance strategies, including divesting from fossil fuels and appropriately resourcing digital products and services to account for long-term care and maintenance.

criteria.title: Fuel Divestment
criteria.description: The organization has divested from fossil fuels and moved its banking, sponsorship, and other affiliations to more responsible partners.

criteria.title: Responsible Finance
criteria.description: The organization engages in flexible financing and responsible budgeting for its digital products and services to accommodate long-term care and maintenance.

data.title: 5.24 Include Organizational Philanthropy Policies
data.description: For-profit organizations have clear philanthropy policies and practices in place to help non-profit organizations build digital capacity and acumen while also engaging their own teams in meaningful work that promotes shared learning and stretch goals.

criteria.title: Philanthropy Policy
criteria.description: The organization has a clear corporate giving policy and creates philanthropic partnerships with strategically aligned organizations.

criteria.title: Voluntary Work
criteria.description: The organization engages in free or volunteer projects, which help its team learn new tools and tactics, while also helping charities and non-profit organizations build capacity.

data.title: 5.25 Plan for a Digital Product or Service's Care and End-of-Life
data.description: Everything ends at some point, planning for if and when a product or service is finalized makes good ethical sense to ensure customers can be transitioned toward a replacement rather than losing access to their data.

criteria.title: End-of-life Care
criteria.description: Establish clear, documented end-of-life guidelines that include data disposal, archiving, file deletion, and so on.

data.title: 5.26 Include E-Waste, Right-To-Repair, and Recycling Policies
data.description: The organization addresses e-waste, right-to-repair, recycling, and related practices in its operations.

criteria.title: E-Waste Policy
criteria.description: The organization has specific policies in place to recycle e-waste and repair owned technology products whenever possible.

criteria.title: Recycling And Repairing
criteria.description: The organization has formed relationships with local partners for e-waste recycling and repair.

criteria.title: Refurbishment Strategy
criteria.description: The organization buys refurbished equipment whenever possible.

data.title: 5.27 Define Performance and Environmental Budgets
data.description: Setting targets and limits regarding your product or service is important for keeping a sustainable mindset. Using budgets, you can declare the remits of which you will work within to ensure your emissions do not fall outside (and monitor your progress through development).

criteria.title: Environmental Budget
criteria.description: The product team has defined, baselined, and documented a clear sustainability and environmental budget criteria that covers the page, user-journey, and digital service levels and metrics (such as a CO2.js score) that are approved by relevant product stakeholders.

criteria.title: Performance Budget
criteria.description: Use tools such as a performance budget to determine the maximum size (goals) your app or website can weigh to reduce the data transfer and HTTP request impact (using metrics like Google Lighthouse).

criteria.title: Measurable Improvements
criteria.description: The product team can measurably show how much the budgeting process improved performance and reduced emissions.

criteria.title: Capacity And Maintenance
criteria.description: The product team invests in resources to build capacity and maintain the budgets over time.

data.title: 5.28 Use Open Source Tools
data.description: The organization has clear policies about using open source tools, including how it gives back to the community and responsibly manages code repositories to reduce waste.

criteria.title: Open Source Policy
criteria.description: The organization has a clear open source policy in place that outlines how it uses open source tools and the practices it supports surrounding open source development.

criteria.title: Collaboration
criteria.description: The organization has a track record of collaboration and community-building around open source principles.

criteria.title: Contribution
criteria.description: The organization regularly contributes to open source community-based projects.
